title: Your chance to quiz John Kay about the future of finance
text:
Your chance to quiz John Kay about the future of finance Claer Barrett Comments 
John Kay, the economist and Financial Times columnist, will be taking questions from readers in a live Q&A Facebook chat on Tuesday September 15 at 4pm BST. 
The event will build on the themes discussed in his latest book, Other People’s Money: Masters of the Universe, or Servants of the People? , in which he probes how the world of high finance has become disconnected from the real economy. More Other People's Money John Kay talks exclusively to the FT about his new book 
To submit a question, or view the event in Facebook, click here . 
An extract from John Kay’s book has been published in FT Money, drawing on hispast experiences on the boards of British banks, and his subsequent re-examination of the financial crisis. 
His central theory is that the complexity of modern finance “has been designed, and has operated principally to benefit, the financial intermediaries rather than the users of financial services”. 
Declaring himself an advocate of “boring banking” , he is a supporter of separating banks’ retail and investment banking operations. But he also believes that reform of the financial services sector has not gone far enough. 
In a podcast with FT Money this month, he said: “My fear is that the only way we’re ever going to get substantive reform is through another crisis — possibly even bigger than the last one.” 
He also questioned the popularity of investment banking as a career choice. “The idea in the 1960s that your cleverest graduates would clamour for places in Goldman Sachs was something you just never imagined could happen,” he added. “What is the opportunity cost of having attracted many of the UK’s brightest people into activities that don’t actually add value for society as whole?” 
FT Money will also be hosting An Evening with John Kay at the FT’s London offices on the evening of Tuesday November 3, where he will talk about the themes of his book, and take questions from readers. Tickets cost £25 and include a signed copy of his book. 
You can book tickets for the event at FT.com/johnkayevent . Related Topics
